title: St Helena's Tourism Grows with More Non-Stop Flights from Johannesburg and Cape Town - Travel And Tour World
text:
The addition of weekly Airlink flights from Johannesburg to St Helena, expected to commence on December 6, 2025, has possibly led to the removal of the island from the list of the world’s most inaccessible places. Along with additional regional flights from mid-December to mid-March for the 2026/2027 summer season, the expansion of the Cape Town regional airport is also expected to strengthen leisure tourism to the island. The Cape Town flights are expected to complement relaxation trips for the 2026/2027 southern summer season from the airport.
The arrival of Airlink, along with increased tourism to the island is expected to strengthen the African travel market. The newest flights add clarity and allow better planning for both local and visiting stakeholders. Avaen is 18 months, drop to 4 months, Helena.
An Exciting Place for Tourism and Adventure Advertisement St Helena, a historically and geographically rich island, has begun attracting more and more tourists due to its array of wildlife and imposing landscapes. Tourists seeking truly unique adventures are drawn to its volcanic soil and rugged isolation, which are unlike any other. Airlink’s forward flight schedule has the potential to grow visitor count due to its air access expansion, especially at peak travel times.
The added air access is a boon to the tourism industry, fueling new package ideas that are more creative than ever. Tourists are able to combine visits to St Helena’s natural attractions and famed sites in and around Cape Town like Table Mountain, the imposing V&A Waterfront, or the Cape Winelands. Tourists who wish to experience a dual-centre vacation are in luck, for the new Cape Town to St Helena flight, which is operational during the southern summer, is preferable for those wanting to celebrate the holidays while enjoying the St Helena mesmerising scenery juxtaposed to the lively offerings of South Africa’s Mother City. Advertisement Everything from avid St Helena history readers wanting to see relics from Napoleon, to tourists seeking the island’s unique wildlife like the St Helena Plover, or its rich marine biodiversity, is certain to benefit.
Promo2: Enhancing Regional Connectivity And Expanding Business Prospects Advertisement Besides stimulating tourism, the new flight timetable is also poised to improve business connectivity between St Helena and both Johannesburg and Cape Town. The weekly flights to Johannesburg continue to be an essential lifeline for residents, business people, and the cargo and service trade to and from the island. As business activity between St Helena and the African mainland expands, the new air services will provide seamless travel for investors and entrepreneurs, promoting a higher level of economic integration between the island and South Africa.
The new flights also create new business partnership opportunities for South African companies, especially in the hospitality, farming, and trade sectors. St Helena’s local economy will be better integrated and the island’s position as a trade and business partner will be enhanced due to the new flights.
A Comprehensive Policy for the Improvement of St Helena’s Tourism Industry
Anticipating developments in Airlink’s operations and its newly offered service of booking flights 18 months in advance corresponds with the wakening of Africa’s travel and aviation sector, where long-term planning and informed accessibility are emerging as critical pillars of the tourism industry. Airlink and the St Helena Government (SHG) are pioneering a new model of regional air service with increased reliability and flexibility. Planning for tourism, travel, and tourism-related income for the country will accelerate the ease of travel, raise the level of national revenues, and grow the sustainable management of the country’s tourism sector.
The added air links to St Helena correspond with the St Helena Government’s desire to promote the island as a prime destination in Southern Africa. The new flight schedule will enhance the level of shore-bound visiting and tourism in the medium to longer term, and will make a sound contribution to the overall development in future tourism.
Promotion of Cultural Exchange and Interest from Abroad
The unique cultural and historical perspective of the Statue of Napoleon have and still makes St Helena a Cultural Exchange Site and a historical mark worth visiting. Floating in the geostrategic universe of the South Atlantic Ocean, St Helena becomes a crossroad and a maritime hub where diverse cultural communes merge. It provides unparalleled experience to the visitors who like to travel and learn about the unique history and culture have developed due to Maritime trade. The development of new flight connections to the remote corners of the world allows new visitors to learn about the unique cultural portrait of the place. These connections will help develop the unique biodiversity and travel industry of the region.
Further to this—the development of the tourism sector of St Helena will give a unique and special experience to cultural tourism. Visitors will have the experience of interaction with the local community combined with professionally designed historical trips and excursions enriched with unique nature- water, lands and climbing. The well planned networks will give more visitors the experience of the unique culture St Helena has to offer. The posture of the region will tell a new story.
Looking Ahead: Continued Growth for St Helena’s Tourism Sector
With another scheduled flight for the next one and a half years, both business and leisure travel for St. Helena will be on the rise. St. Helena’s tourism will certainly be positively impacted, as both head and add-on ticket access help grow the reach. Flexible additional flights will certainly allow for the St. Helena area to be more popular and accessible among a wider audience during the busy summer travel season.
St. Helena is an underdeveloped yet popular area. The flight offerings greatly benefit travel professionals not only in Southern Africa, but globally as well. The partnerships and plans put together can greatly help market St. Helena to the proper audiences in need of adventure, unique culture, and history.
